title: Can I include my california First program into a bankruptcy
question: Last year we had a contractor come out to our home and gave us a quote for our home repairs, our total repair cost were just over $40,000 we were told we didn't need credit to qualify for these type of loans as long as the home had equity and all my mortage payments were on time with no 30 day late payments. so after all set and done they end up putting a lien on our home for $45,000 mine Financial sititauation has change a bit and I'm just afraid I won't be able to keep up with these payments I was thinking of just filling for either chapter 7 or 13 bankruptcy since I do have lots of collections and late payments.
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy estate,Credit repair,Debt,Child support lien,Lien,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate
answers:
As already mentioned, you need to see a local attorney to get your answers ... we don't have nearly enough information to answer fully.
Having said that, I should simply point out in response to your primary question that liens remain after BK. You will discharge your personal liability on that 45k but they will still have a lien on your house which will have to be paid eventually.

All your assets and liabilities, income and expenses MUST be included in a Bankruptcy, you do not get to pick and chose. However, that does not mean that you will lose your home. You need to retain an experienced CA Bankruptcy attorney right away! THIS IS NOT LEGAL ADVICE! YOU NEED TO SPEAK TO AN ATTORNEY WHO IS LICENSED IN YOUR STATE FOR LEGAL ADVICE. This is merely suggestions for you to think about in discussing your situation with the local attorney.

First, you must list every debt and every asset in any bankruptcy. Thus your desire to not "include my home or my cars" will not be met. But merely listing them does not mean you will lose them.

Second on the house, if the FMV is LESS than the amount owed on prior mortgages, and is your residence, subsequent liens you can probably avoid. Whether you qualify for ch 13 is another issue though.


Third, cars can be dealt with in various ways depending on the facts, including how long you owned them, any traded in, interest rates, etc.


Fourth, asking your question implies you have not seen an attorney and that is a mistake. See an experienced bankruptcy attorney next. OTher issues and facts can affect your case too so I will point out some of those next.

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!

Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!

Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.

But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.

Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.

You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.
